title: 37-Melt-Runoff Delaying Characteristics of Gangotri Glacier.
abstract: Most of the Himalayan basins have considerable snow and glacier covered areas. The melt contribution in such rivers augments their flows in the lean season, thereby reducing the variation in water availability. Depending upon the prevailing climatic conditions, the runoff contribution from the glaciers in the Himalayan rivers starts in May after depletion of accumulated seasonal snow. Usually melt contribution from these glaciers continues till October. The melt water generated in the glacierized basin appears as runoff at the snout of glacier with a time-lag. Changes in delaying characteristics of the runoff over the melt season can be understood by studying the variation in time to peak (tn) and time-lag (t1) between melt generation and its emergence as runoff. In the recent study, the runoff delaying characteristics of the Gangotri Glacier in the Garhwal Himalayas (glacierized area 286 km2; drainage area 556 km2) have been studied. For this purpose, hourly discharge and temperature data were collected near the snout of the glacier (approx 4000 m) for the entire ablation period (May—October, 2004). The diurnal variations in the hydrograph and temperature observed under clear weather provided useful information for this study. In the early stages of the ablation period, poor drainage network and stronger storage characteristics of the glaciers due to the presence of seasonal snow cover resulted in a much delayed response of melt water, providing a higher t, and ti,. A comparison of runoff delaying parameters with discharge ratio clearly indicated that changes in time-lag and time to peak are inversely correlated with variations in discharge.

title: Bayes estimators of parameters of Poisson type exponential class software model considering generalized Poisson and gamma priors
abstract: The paper deals with the estimation problem of Poisson type Exponential Class model which has wide application in software reliability. This model consists of two parameters namely, the total number of failures and the failure rate. Considering the behaviour of the parameter, total number of failure and limitation of Poisson distribution, a generalized Poisson distribution has been proposed as a prior for this parameter. Further, an inverted Gamma prior has been selected for failure rate in view of its property. The Bayes estimators have been obtained considering these priors under Squared Error Loss Function. To study the performance of obtained estimators, these estimators have been compared with corresponding maximum likelihood estimators on the basis of a Monte Carlo simulation study.

title: Magnetospheric electron temperatures inferred from whistler observations at low latitudes
abstract: Whistler observations during night times made at low latitude Indian ground stations Jammu (geomag lat 22 26'N, L= 1 17), Namital (geomag lat, 19 1'N, LŦ1 16) and Varanasi (geomag lat, 14 55yN, L= 1 11) are used to deduced electron temperatures in the vicinity of the magnetospheric equator The accurate curve fitting and parameter estimation technique are used to compute nose frequency and equatorial electron densities from the dispersion measurements of short whistlers recorded at Jammu, Namital and Varanasi These computed parameters are further used to estimate the magnetospheric electron temperatures from the dispersion analysis of short whistlers observed at low latitudes which are in good agreement with the results reported by other workers

title: 紧密纺的不同工艺技术
abstract: 介绍了紧密纺纱法的原理及其分类,重点介绍了立达公司的Com4,绪森公司的Elite,青泽公司的ComPACT3,Cognetex公司的Com4wool,马佐里公司的Olfil和日本丰田公司的吸气式紧密纺装置,并介绍了Officine Gaudiuo公司的纯机械式和瑞士Hans Stahlecker公司的Rocos磁性紧密纺装置,指出紧密纺纱法可获得毛羽少,强力高的优质纱,建议紧密纺采用优质钢领,并在空间上与普通环锭纺隔离开操作.

title: Pentoxifylline as an adjuvant to surgery and antibiotics in the treatment of perforation peritonitis: a prospective, randomised placebo-controlled study
abstract: Introduction: In animal models and human trials, pentoxifylline has shown beneficial pharmacological effects in the treatment of septic shock. We evaluated the role of pentoxifylline in the treatment of perforation peritonitis, as an adjuvant to surgery and standard antibiotic treatment.Methods: A prospective, randomised placebocontrolled trial was conducted on 50 patients with perforation peritonitis. 25 patients were randomised to the test group and 25 patients to the control group. In addition to standard treatment, the test group of patients received pentoxifylline 200 mg per day as an adjuvant for three days. The endpoints of the study were to evaluate the condition of the wound in the postoperative period, APACHE II score and total duration of hospital stay.Results: Both groups were comparable in all aspects. There were 23 male and two female patients in the test group, and 20 male and five female patients in the control group (p-value is 0.021). Mean age was 37.9+/-10.5 years in the test group and 33.8+/-11.0 years in the control group (p-value is 0.186). The APACHE II score in the test group and in the control group was statistically not significant (p-value is 0.661). In the test group, seven (28 percent) patients had wound infection and in the control group, 13 (52 percent) patients had wound infection (p-value is 0.083). The mean postoperative hospital stay in the test group was 6.8+/-2.1 days and in the control group, it was 11.2+/-5.2 days (p-value is 0.001).Conclusion: Pentoxifylline improved the outcome by significantly decreasing the length of the hospital stay and the rate of wound infection.

title: PCR-RFLP analysis of β1 domain of MHC class II β region in Aseel and immunodivergent chicken lines
abstract: BL-βII region of chicken MHC was analyzed in Aseel (Peela) a native breed of chicken with much less history of selection for economic traits and high yielding white plumaged Synthetic Broiler Dam Line (SDL), divergently selected for response to sheep RBCs (SRBC). Response to SRBC (0.5% suspension, i/v) was estimated by HA test after 5 days post immunization and high (HSRBC) and low (LSRBC) responding lines to SRBC were generated. DNA was isolated from extreme responders of divergent lines after second generation (F2) of selection as well as randomly chosen individuals of Aseel. BL-βII region was amplified as 277 bp using specific primers. PCR products were purified and digested with Taq I enzyme. Subsequent to polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and silver staining a total of two genotypes i.e. AA and AC were observed in SDL birds with genotypes frequencies of AA genotype as 0.9 and 0.3 in …

title: Evaluation of different fungicides to control Alternaria leaf spot of chilli (Alternaria solani Ell. Mart.) under in vitro and in vivo conditions
abstract: Experiment was conducted under field conditions in kharif season of 2003 and 2004 to evaluate the performance of six fungicides against leaf spot of chilli caused by Alternaria solani. In first year trial (Kharif 2003), the performance of Carina was best among all other fungicides. The percentage of disease index (PDI) in untreated plots at 45,60 and 75 DAT were 15.17, 20.24 and 24.19 percent, while on the same dates of transplanting in Carma treated plots, PDI was 3.70, 4.44 and 4.93 respectively. In second year trial (kharif 2004), the results were almost similar to previous year. However, it was observed that at 75 DAT there was no significant difference in PDI among Carma, Quintal, Dithane M-45 and Bavistin treated plots. Under laboratory conditions it was found that, Carma was also found much effective than other fungicides and there was no significant difference among Carma, Quintal, Dithane M-45 and …

title: Evaluation of elite cultures for resistance te bacterial leaf blight of rice
abstract: Xanthomonas oryzae pv. oryzae (Xoo) is considered as one of the most destructive diseases, especially in irrigated and rainfed lowland ecosystems (DRR 1975-2007). Cultivation of resistant varieties is the best solution to manage the disease as chemical control is not successful and economical. Although, thirty BLB resistant genes have been identified and characterized from d. verse sources, the effectiveness of different BLB resistant genes varies due to difference in virulence profile of the pathogen population ill different geographical legions. Gene diversification is one of the approaches 1O sustain the resistance for a long period and this can be achieved by scouting genes, either from cultivated germplasm or wild species (Vikal et al 2004). In the present study, we evaluated 27 selected cultures for resistance to multiple isolates of the BLB pathogen.

title: Impact of Participatory Varietal Selection on Varietal Diversification in Northern India
abstract: The Department for International Development (DFID) Project carried out during 2002-03 to 2004-05 in the state of Haryana (India) aimed at increasing wheat productivity in a sustainable way, promoting resource conservation technologies (RCTs) for the north western India, increasing the profitability of farmers in rice wheat system and training the farmers on RCTs and seed production. This paper is based on the findings of base line survey, wheat crop evaluation by farmers before and at maturity, and survey of 100 farmers in the project area. The project has successfully achieved more varietal replacement. Area under PBW 343 has declined and other varieties of similar potential are being adopted. PBW 502 was ranked first by the farmers followed by PBW 343, HD 2687, UP 2338, WH 711, PBW 373, UP 2425, RAJ 3765 and WH 542. The year wise correlation between ranking of varieties was highly significant which supported the farmers’ perception that the performance of the varieties was consistent over the years. Mean score of PBW 502 and PBW 343 showed superiority over other varieties. The farmers preferred PBW 502 for dense earhead, bold grain and more tillering. The farmers appreciated the concept of demonstration of all the improved varieties at one site.

title: Response of mustard varities to date of sowing and moisture conservation practice under scarce moisture condition
abstract: A field experiment was conducted during Rabi seasons of 2001–2002 and 2003–2004, to study the response of mustard varieties to date of sowing and moisture conservation practices under scarce moisture condition. On the basis of over all consideration of growth, development, heat unit accumulation, heat unit efficiency, yield attributes, yield and net profit, the crop sown on 15th October resulted in, maximum growth and yield during both the year, while delayed sowing lowered the growth and yield. Variety “Vaibhav” prove to be the most promosing in growth, yield and net return as compared to variety “Urwashi” under the test. Among the moisture conservation practices, paddy straw mulch proves to be better over moisture conservation practices applied during the experimentation.

title: Efficacy of Herbicides on Weeds and Yield of Transplanted Rice (Oryza sativa L.)
abstract: Rice (Oryza sativa L.) is staple food crop of India growing over an area of 44 million hectares with production about 93 million tonnes. The productivity of rice is (2.8 t/ha) lower as against world average 3.9 t/ha. Severe competition from weeds is one of the important factors deterring productivity and sustainability. Transplanted rice is infested with wide variety of weeds viz., grasses, sedges and broad-leaved weeds. The average loss in grain yield by unchecked weeds is reported to be 32.0%(Singh et al., 2007). The use of herbicides offers selective and economical control of weeds right from the beginning till harvest. Butachlor and pretilachlor are effective against weed species, but these are very specific and narrow spectrum of activity. Continuous use of these herbicides leads to weed flora shift and development of herbicide resistance. Therefore, new and alternate herbicides need evaluation to widen application …

title: Verrucous papillomatous lesion of post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis: Fine needle aspiration diagnosis of an unusual presentation

title: Impact of Fly Ash-Soil Amendment on Vegetable Production
abstract: The present paper discusses the prospects of utilization of fly ash in agriculture sector to get enhanced yields of vegetable crops in the degraded soils.   The physico-chemical properties, such as pH, EC, porosity, bulk density (BD), water holding capacity (WHC), cation exchange capacity (CEC), dehyrogenase activity and texture of the soil, after mixing with fly ash were found to improve the soil properties greatly, making the amended soil richer in essential nutrient elements and more fertile.   Amendment of fly ash enhances the growth performance of selected vegetable viz, carrot (Daucus carota- family Umbelliferae)  and radish (Raphanus sativus – family Cruciferae).  The pot experiments were carried out with mixed soil, fly ash does being 5%, 10% and 20% by weight, in addition to the usual application of recommended dose of NPK fertilizer.  The vegetables grown in fly ash amended soil have also shown higher yield compared to non-amended soil.  The fly ash-soil amendment technology will thus go a long way in greatly enhancing and improving the agricultural production and economy of the state.

title: Synthesis, Mechanistic and Kinetic Study of 2, 4, 5-Trichloroaniline Phosphate Monoester
abstract: Kinetic measurement of the hydrolysis of 2, 4, 5-trichloroaniline phosphate mono-ester has been made in acid (0.1-6.0 mol dm3 HCl) solution at 97±0.5 ºC supported the hypothesis that acid catalysis occurs only when electron attracting substituent is present in the aryl part. Pseudo first order rate coefficients have been calculated. Conjugate acid, neutral and mononegative species have been found to be reactive and contribute in the overall rates. The rate coefficients estimated are fairly in good agreement with the observed rates. Bond fission, molecularity and order of reaction have been supported by Arrhenius parameters, Zucker-Hammett hypothesis, concentration and solvent effect etc. Comparative isokinetic rate data of similarly substituted other amino phosphate mono-esters, supported PN bond fission.

title: CXCR5-CXCL13 expression regulates cellular mechanisms involved in prostate cancer cell invasion and correlates with prostate cancer progression
abstract: 289Chemokine-chemokine receptor interactions play significant roles in prostate cancer metastasis. Here we show that CXCR5 is functionally expressed by prostate cancer cell lines (LNCaP and PC3). Correspondingly, the ligand for CXCR5, CXCL13, was secreted by bone marrow (endothelial, osteoblast, and osteoclast) cells due to the host response following prostatic neoplasia and is elevated in patients with prostate cancer, compared to those with PIN or hyperplasia. Both LNCaP and PC3 cell lines express higher levels of CXCR5 than normal prostatic epithelial cells (PrEC). After CXCL13-engagement, prostate cancer cells displayed a higher migration and invasive potential in vitro, which was significantly reduced by CXCR5 blockade. CXCL13 also increased collagenases (MMP-1 and -13), stromelysins (MMP-3 and -10), and gelatinases (MMP-2 and -9) expression by both LNCaP and PC3 cell lines. Our …

title: BGA diversity in paddy fields and wetlands of Satna (MP)
abstract: The present study deals with the distribution of Blue Green Algae (BGA) in paddy fields and wetlands at different localities of Satna (MP). The paddy fields are best thriving grounds for growth of BGA because of the prevailing high temperature, high humidity and water logged condition during the rice growing season. Importance of BGA in soil fertility and nitrogen economy of soil has been well documented in tropical countries. During the course of present investigation a total of 112 unicellular, non-heterocystous and heterocystous species of BGA belonging to genera Microcystis, Chroococcus, Gloeocapsa, Gloeothece, Aphanocapsa, Aphanothece, Merismopedia, Dactylococcopsis, Chlorogloea, Arthrospira, Spirulina, Oscillatoria, Porphyrosiphon Phormidium, Lyngbya, Schizothrix, Microcoleus, Anabaena, Nostoc, Aulosira, Scytonema, Tolypothrix,

title: Development of Physical Indicators and Web Enabled Information System for Baraichpur Village
abstract: In 21st century also, about three-fourth of the population of India is living in rural areas. Though, growth of urban areas is higher in comparison to the rural areas, integrated development of rural areas is required to achieve the sustainable development at regional level. Development of physical infrastructure at village level is prerequisite for the overall development of the region as well as nation. In the light of this, main aim of the study is to derive the indicators to find the status of physical infrastructure ie water supply, sanitation, electricity, telephone and their interrelation with different social classes at village level. Detailed study has been carried out for Baraichpur village, Ladwa block of Kurushestra district in Haryana state, India. For this purpose, IKONOS panchromatic and multispectral merged imagery of February 2005 has been used for the preparation of large scale (1: 2000) base map. Analysis shows that this village is well served through electricity and transportation network. Public tap and hand-pump are main source of the drinking water supply. But status of sanitation is very poor as just 28% households have sanitation facility inside the house. Information at village level needs to be available widely for the planning and decision-making at different stages and thus, it has been integrated through web enabled information system.

title: Resistance To Eastern African Stem Rust Isolates With Broad Virulence In: US and Cimmyt Wheat
abstract: The stem rust resistance gene Sr31 was derived from rye and has been used as the main component for stem rust resistance in many wheat cultivars worldwide. Isolates of Puccinia graminis f. sp. tritici with virulence to Sr31 were identified from Uganda in 1999. Similar virulence was observed in Kenya in 2003 and 2004. An isolate collected from Uganda in 1999 and an isolate collected from Kenya in 2004, identified as race TTKS, were used to evaluate US and CIMMYT wheat. Cultivars and advanced breeding lines (450) in various wheat classes from US and 152 bread-wheat cultivars from CIMMYT, Mexico, were tested for resistance to these two stem rust isolates. Resistance to race TTKS was detected in all classes of wheat with the following frequencies: 16% of US hard red spring wheat, 48% of the US hard red winter wheat, 27% of US soft red winter wheat, 50% of durum wheat, and 16% of CIMMYT spring bread wheat. Resistance in the hard red winter wheat was primarily due to Sr24, and resistance in the soft red winter wheat was primarily due to Sr36. Resistance to race TTKS due to SrTmp was present but in a low frequency. Genes conferring resistance in the spring wheat are not known, but Sr24 may be present in some lines. The adult plant resistance of some selected wheat cultivars will be assessed in the field in Kenya.

title: ANAESTHETIC MANAGEMENT OF A PATIENT WITH PRIMARY PULMONARY HYPERTENSION UNDERGOING CHOLECYSTECTOMY–A Case Report
abstract: Patients with primary pulmonary hypertension, a rare disease of the pulmonary vasculature occasionally present for anaesthesia. These patients are considered high risk for anaesthesia due to increased risk of peri-operative cardiovascular complications. Anaesthesia requires invasive cardiovascular monitoring and maintenance of stable pulmonary and systemic haemodynamics. This is a case report of a 50 year old lady with primary pulmonary hypertension (PPH) who successfully underwent cholecystectomy under a combination of abdominal field block and thoracic epidural anaesthesia. This report highlights the problems and management of patients with primary pulmonary hypertension.

title: Evaluation of sulfonylurea herbicides to control weeds in transplanted rice
abstract: Rice is an important food crop in India, but its average yield is rather low. It faces various production constraints, including competition from weeds that can reduce yield by 25-53%. Infestation commonly occurs 15-45 d after transplanting (DAT)(Subhaiah and Sreedevi 2000).

title: Effect of GA3 and NAA on growth and yield of seed potato
abstract: An experiment was conducted at Gwalior during cropping season 2004-05 to compare the field grown plants treated with GA 3-10 ppm (Dip) and NAA-50 ppm (two sprays at 25 and 50 days after planting) with untreated plants in terms of their morphology, tuber number and yield. For pre-planting treatments, tubers were dipped in GA 3 solution for 30 minutes and then spread on the floor, while the tubers of NAA and control were left on the wellventilated floor for sprouting. In randomized block design tubers were planted at 60 x 20 cm spacing in plot size of 21 x 24 m with eight replications. Recommended package of practices were followed. The haulms were destroyed at 80 DAP. The GA 3 application recorded significantly higher plant height (25.70 cm) and number of stems per plant (5.10) at 30 DAP. Plant growth regulators made significant differences in number and weight of tubers. The GA 3 gave significantly …

title: Association of Surface Latent Heat Flux with Hurricane Isabel
abstract: Remote sensing has emerged as an important technique for monitoring and mapping natural hazards. Land, ocean and atmospheric parameters are now commonly retrieved using multi-sensor data. The present study focuses on the air-sea interactions associated with hurricane Isabel, which hit the east coast of the United States on September 18, 2003. Hurricane Isabel is considered to be one of the most significant and severe tropical cyclones, as it affected the entire east coast in many ways. We have observed anomalous values of surface latent heat flux (SLHF) at the time of the hurricane along its track, where such anomalies provide characteristic information about the path and development of the hurricane. Changes in SLHF are found to be directly related with the intensity of the hurricane, and can help in determining the actual path and landfall information. Significant increase in SLHF up to 200 percent has …

title: Model study on dynamics of open fire in Underground coal mines under varied air flow
abstract: A small scale model representing mine gallery has been designed constructed and installed at Central Mining Research Institute, Dhanbad, India. The basic purpose of the model gallery was to study the complex phenomenon of open fires in simulated underground mine condition.   The model is 19 m long having two segments. The first one is 10m long insulated rectangular segment having cross section of 45 cm x 57 cm. Insulation lining of fire bricks leaves space of 13 cm x 13 cm for air flow through the model. The second segment is 9m long 30 m diameter, circular section having a centrifugal exhaust fan installed at its end.   Two sets of experiments were carried out in the model at air velocities 1.0 m/s and 1.5 m/s using coal blocks of 5 cm thickness lined in all four inner sides of the model. The coal lining was made for a length of 3 m starting from 1 m of the model entry. After establishing the desired air flow inside the model, fire was initiated artificially at the beginning of the coal zone. Governing parameters such as gas concentration, temperature, pressure drop across fire zone, air velocity and dust concentration inside the model were continuously monitored for about 8 to 9 hours.   The paper highlights the salient features of the model, instrumentation system, experimental procedure, important observations, results of the experiment and correlation of findings with particular reference to gas concentration, temperature and fire size.

title: AERONET: New aerosol products, data access and reanalysis of field data for mixtures of fine and coarse mode aerosols
abstract: The AERONET program has experienced rapid expansion through ten years of international collaboration and recent development of new aerosol products. Approximately 130 permanent sites are distributed across all continents and small islands. New retrievals will be presented of fine and coarse mode aerosol optical depth, size distribution and single scattering albedo based on the Dubovik and King inversion with a spheroid model as applied to historical AERONET data specifically for aerosol regimes dominated by coarse particle aerosols and mixtures of fine and coarse particles. In the case of Beijing, China, a regionally generated coarse mode mixed with fine mode shows considerable dynamics between increasing radius with optical depth in the fine mode anthropogenic aerosols and increase in single scattering albedo. Long term observations of other coarse mode fine mode mixtures of biomass burning …

title: Damping of ion-cyclotron whistler waves through ionospheric plasma
abstract: The propagation features of ion-cyclotron whistler waves through the hydrogen, helium and oxygen plasma are studied. Expression for temporal damping, spatial damping and the time development of wave amplitude is derived from the modified theory of cyclotron damping of ion-cyclotron whistler wave including thermal effect. It is shown that the temporal damping is dominant for wave frequencies closer to the ion gyrofrequencies. The variations in plasma conditions cause variation in sudden commencement of cyclotron damping, which occurs after finite time of propagation of ion whistlers. The results have been used to explain the sudden cut-off of the amplitude of ion whistler wave observed by rockets and satellites in the terrestrial ionosphere. It is shown that the present study can be used to estimate ion temperature of the plasma.

title: Effect of nitrogen, phosphorus and sulphur on yield attributes and yield of taramira (Eruca sativa L.)
abstract: Among oil seeds, the rap~ seed and mustard group rank next to groundnut with respect to production. Taramira (Eruca sativa L.) is a neglected member of this group which has tremendous potential even under resource constraints. This crop is grown on a wide range of soils under conserved moisture. Being hard in nature, it is the alternative season. The oil of a Taramira is mainly used for illdustrial purposes. Its cake is not only used as concentrate for animals but also used as manure for enhancing the physical condition and fertility of the soil. The average productivity of this crop has been very low and quite insatiable over the year.The main reason being its cultivation on marginal soils, which are not only thirsty but also hungry. Besides nitrogen, phosphorus and sulphur also play an important role in augmenting the productivity of crop. Therefore, the present investigation was undertaken to study the performance of …

title: Effect of plant spacing on growth, yield and seed quality in restorer lines of sunflower hybrids
abstract: A field trial was conducted to study the effect of plant spacing on growth and yield of different restorer lines of sunflower hybrids during the winter season of 1996-97 and 1998-99 at BHU Research Farm, Varanasi. Significant variation in restorer lines in all the physiological and reproductive characters were observed during both the years. Among the restorer lines, 6D-l recorded the highest leaf area index, crop growth rate, net assimilation rate, more number of seeds capitulum-l (365.8), 1000-seed weight (44.08 g) and seed yield plantl(12.69 g) than AK-IR and P-35 R. This ultimately led to maximum seed yield (10.8 q ha-I) by 6D-l. Similarly, spacing SI (40 x 15 cm) registered 63.4, 50.9 and 20.0% more seed yield than S4 (70 x 20 cm), S3 (60 x 20 cm) and S2 (50 x 15cm) respectively. It was further observed that plant population had a linear functional relationship with seed yield (Y= 3.73+ 4.52 x).

title: Discharge characteristics of chimney weir under free-flow conditions
abstract: The assumption of a constant coefficient of discharge in the linear head-discharge relationship of a chimney weir is reinvestigated. Based on dimensional analysis and subsequent experiments conducted with three different chimney weirs at various crest heights and channel widths, it is found that the coefficient of discharge in the linear relationship is not a constant, but is found to vary with the ratio of head to altitude,  half-vertex angle in the form of  w being the half crest width;  P being the crest height; and the channel width contraction ratio,  C being the channel width. A linear regression equation correlating the coefficient of discharge with the above variables is proposed that, along with the linear head-discharge relationship, provides an accurate prediction of free-flow discharge.

title: In situ resistivity studies of 200 MeV 107Ag14+-ion irradiated n-GaAs epitaxial layers
abstract: The effect of 200 MeV 107Ag14+-ion irradiation on the electrical transport behavior of Si-doped n-GaAs epitaxial layers has been investigated employing in situ resistivity measurements. The n-GaAs epitaxial layers grown by metallorganic chemical vapor deposition method have carrier concentrations of 3×1015, 3×1016 and 3×1017 cm−3. The fluence of 200 MeV 107Ag14+ ion is varied from 2×108 to 5×1011 ions cm−2. It is observed that in all the three epitaxial layers, resistivity initially remains constant up to a critical fluence. After this critical fluence, which depends on the initial carrier concentration in the layer, there is a rapid increase in resistivity with fluence. The swift heavy-ion irradiation-induced deep-level defects, which trap the free carriers and causes the mobility degradation, are responsible for enhancement in resistivity. The swift heavy ion traversing through the semiconductor, transfers its energy via …

title: Chamber method of ventilation-a proven technology for reducing leakage of air into the goaf
abstract: Improvement in climatic conditions at workings in mine having surface cracks by increasing fan capacity is a risky proposition. It may lead to spontaneous heating in the mine due to leakage of air from surface caused by increase in cumulative pressure drop measured from the surface. The above problem cannot be addressed by conventional ventilation system.   Anew method of ventilation named "Chamber method of ventilation" have been evolved to ventilate the workings under the situation mentioned above, the method is superimposed on the existing ventilation system of the mine without much modifications or any adverse effect on ventilation of remaining districts. The method was successfully implemented at 1 & 2 incline mines, Jhanjra project, Eastern Coalfields Limited (ECL) to reduce surface air leakage for control of fire in a working longwall panel and for improvement in climatic condition.

title: Relationship of sulphur and selenium in soils and forage crops
abstract: Selenium is not considered as an essential element for plant growth, but the health of animals is dependent upon its level in forage crops. Among the various factors, the level of S in the growth mediurn plays an important role in regulating the accumulation of selenium by plants (Dhillon et 01. 1992). Keeping this in view, the present investigation was undertaken to study the concentration of Se and S and their relationship in various forage crops and soils ofeastern Uttar Pradesh. Plant samples of fodder crops such as maize, cowpea, berseem, jawor, bajra, oat, napier grass and lucerne were collected from various parts of Faizabad district. Soil samples were also drawn from the same sites along with the plant samples to know the status of available Se and sulphur. After processing, the samples were analysed for sulphur content by turbidimetric method (Chesnin & Yien 1951) and selenium by the method described …

title: Identification of GTG specific microsatellite DNA in river buffalo (Bubalus bubalis) genome
abstract: Genomic library of Murrah buffalo was constructed plasmid pBluescript SK II (-) vector. The size of the inserts in the recombinant clone ranged from 0.3-1.0 kb. The primary screening of the genomic library was done to identify the clones carrying insert having (GTG) trinucleotide repeat sequences. Slot blot hybridization of plasmid minipreps helped in selecting the particular clone having more repeats in the insert DNA. The Southern hybridization of linerarized recombinant plasmid DNA could confirm the identify of (GTG) 5 repeats in cloned insert DNA.

title: Why use more propofol as 2% formulation?
abstract: Propofol is believed to be the most widely used sedative in the adult intensive care unit (ICU). Its pharmacokinetic profile produces easily controllable sedation.1 Propofol is prepared in 10% intralipid emulsion (0.1 g ml−1 of fat). Critically ill patients may have impaired lipid tolerance and they may also be the recipients of total parenteral nutrition, hence, ‘creaming’ may be a consequence.2 Because of the problem of fat load we chose to introduce 2% formulation. We observed that waking of some patients using 2% propofol was delayed and the total cost of propofol supplied increased. The cause for this was not clear.We retrospectively surveyed our use of propofol during periods of changeover from 1 to 2%. We reviewed the ICU charts of all patients admitted from September 1998 to February 1999 who received propofol (either 1% or 2%) with or without alfentanil. Patients receiving midazolam, fentanyl, morphine or …

title: The etching characteristics of nuclear tracks in glass detectors
abstract: [en] The etching characteristics of fission tracks are studied in a number of glass samples of varying silica content. A comparative study of etching behaviour has been made by comparing the calculated value of bulk etch rate for each glass. The present investigation suggests that bulk etch rate increases with the decrease in silica content of glasses. A minimum value of bulk etch rate is observed for pure silica glass.(author)

title: Economics of pigeonpea (Cajanus cajan L.) based intercropping systems under varied planting patterns in dry lands of eastern UP
abstract: see more details var. GT 1 and okra var. Parbhanikranthi) and 3 planting patterns of pigeon pea (60 cm normal planting (A), 30+ 90 cm paired row planting (B) and 40+ 80 cm paired row planting (C)) were studied. The performance of pigeon pea was not markedly affected when it was intercropped with either black gram or sesame. However, pigeon pea+ okra reduced the pigeon pea grain yields significantly (by 30.5%(A), 23.2%(B), 25.5%(C), compared with sole crop yields). Despite reduced pigeon pea grain yield, pigeon pea+ okra recorded an increase in pigeon pea equivalent yield, under all the planting patterns with the highest increase under normal planting (31.1%). The pigeon pea equivalent yield, gross returns returns Subject Category: Propertiessee more details and net returns from all the intercropping systems were higher than their respective sole crops. The highest gross returns were obtained with pigeon pea (A)+ okra (Rs 53 437 (1996-97); Rs 37 499 (1997-98)). However, the net returns, benefit: cost ratio, value: cost ratio and monetary advantage index values were highest in pigeon pea+ sesame intercropping systems, irrespective of the planting pattern of pigeon pea.

title: Women's role in rice-wheat farming in Uttar Pradesh
abstract: The paper attempts to examine the nature and pattern of employment of men and women farmers in rice-wheat production system, based on data collected from a random sample of 160 households (consisting of 155 male headed and 5 women headed households) from seven villages of Kada block in Kausambi district of Uttar Pradesh, adopting rapid rural appraisal procedure. The data pertained to the year 1997-98. The study revealed that in spite of larger number of workers per household (4.66) on an average, in small size-groups, the number of dependents was less (1.54) due to their finding off-farm work, as against high dependency ratio (1.70) in large size-groups of holdings. The gender division of labour as well as participation in rice-wheat farming is not pronounced. Women farmers were intensively involved in crop and livestock production and in processing of farm produce such as cleaning, drying …

title: Incidence of Uroleucon compositae, Etiella zinckenella and wilt on Lathyrus sativus l.
abstract: Seasonal incidence of aphid Uroleucon compositae Theobald and response of seven khesari varieties against U. compositae Theobalt, Etiella zinckenella Treit sehke and wilt were studied during rabi 1996-97 at College of Agriculture, Gwalior. The aphid remained active from 14th Feb. to 7th March resulting in 9.77 per cent plant infestation. No population of predators was observed. Against U. composite, varieties PUSA-24 and Selection 505 had less plant infestation, ie 3.4 & 6.2 per cent, respectively. Minimum aphid population was recorded in PUSA-24 (14.7 per 5 cm twig) and maximum in BIOR-202 (45.9 per 5 cm. twig). Against E. zinckenella, minimum pod damage (4.82 per cent) was recorded in IVT-17 and maximum in selection 505 (24.52 per cent). However, varieties IVT-17 and RL 5-6 recording 20.07 and 22.01 per cent loss in the weight of grain, respectively, were found to be less susceptible while varieties LS-157, selection 505 and Bo-01-208 (28.42 to 31.42 per cent loss) were highly susceptible. No symptoms of wilt were observed in the varieties Bo-01-208 and RL 5-6.

title: Inheritance and allelic relationships between genes conferring resistance to Xanthomonas campestris pv. Oryzae (ishiyama) dye in rice (Oryza sativa L.)
abstract: The inheritance of resistance to a pathotype IX05 collected from north western India was studied in three lines of rice B 76, ARC 10464 and CNGS 20083. These lines were crossed to a susceptible cultivar Taichung Native 1 to generate F1, F2 and F3 generations. The reaction of F1 and segregation pattern in F2 and F3 generations suggest that the resistance of B 76 and CNGS 20083 was conditioned by a dominant and a recessive gene respectively. Breeding lines ARC 10464 carried two independently inherited dominant genes. Since the F2 generations obtained from intercrosses of these three lines segregated for susceptible plants it is concluded that B 76, ARC 10464 and CNGS 20083 have differentgenes conferring resistance to pathotype IXC5 of X. c. pv. oryzae.

title: A69-Studies on Heterosis for Certain Physiological and Biochemical Parameters in Rice

title: Nutritive Value of Jungle Rice Echinochloa colonum) Grass for Goats
abstract: Jungle rice (Echinochloa colonum) grass contained CP 5.60, CF 33.75, EE 2.0, NFE 46.15, TA 12.80, Ca 0.39 and P 0.08% on DM basis. Five Barbari kids of about 5 m of age (14.47±2.2S kg B.W.) were fed on fresh jungle rice grass ad-libitum for 30 d. The voluntary DM infake was 5.24±0.22 kg/100 kg body weight. The grass contained 2.51±0.43% DCP and 47.70±l.96% TDN, The daiiy gain in body weight was 26.67 g/head. The nutrient digesttbilities were sattsfactory and all the goats showed positive balance for N but the balances of Ca and P were negative. Hence it is concluded that the jungle rice can not meet the DCP, Ca and F requrements of the growing goats.

title: Variation of diurnal anisotropy during minimum of solar activity cycles 20 and 21
abstract: Harmonic analysis technique was employed to study the variation of the amplitude and phase of the diurnal anisotropy during the period 1964-87 including two reversal of total solar magnetic field and three solar minimum 1964-65 (+), 1976 (+) and 1986-87 (+). We observed that during minimum of 1976 (+) when the north polar magnetic field is positive, the phase of the diurnal anisotropy shifts lo earlier hours from the 1800 hrs corotation direction as reported by convection-diffusion model

title: Increase in NADH-glutamate dehydrogenase in roots and leaves of Vigna radiata (L) Wilezek ev. Pusa baisakhi during lead enrichment
abstract: Enzymes of ammonia assimilation ie GDH and GS and total soluble protein content of 5d old root and leaves of Vigna radiata (L) Wilczek cv. Pusa baisakhi seedlings were determined. Glutamate dehydrogenase activity (NADH-dependent) in-creased considerably in the plant parts up to 2.0 mm P6+ 2 supply whereas total soluble protein content was decreased during the stress. Glutamine synthetase activity, however, could not be detected in crude homogenate at this stage. Our data suggest a possible role of aminating GDH activity in mungbean see-dlings under Pb* toxicity when GS-GOGAT route is inhibited.L-Glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH; EC 1.4. 1.3) catalyses reductive amination of a-ketoglutarate into glutamate by incorporation of-NH2 group has now been questioned as a key enzyme for ammonia assimilation because of its reversible nature and low affinity to the substrate'. However, a possible aminating role of GDH under certain defined conditions espe-cially under stresses where normal GS-GOGAT route gets inhibited is to be worked out. The present paper reports response of this controversial enzyme of ammonia assimila-tion in the young seedlings of mung bean during lead toxicity.

title: Effects of Herbicide Mixtures and Sequential Applications on Relative Composition of Weed Flora in Transplanted Rice
abstract: In a system approach besides crop, land preparation, cultural practices and weed control methods cause considerable change in the weed flora. The simultaneous application of more than one herbicide in a mixture is increasingly becoming a standard practice in modern weed control strategies, particularly in absence of an effective broad spectrum herbicide to control highly deverse weed populations. Response of weeds to different herbicides have been weB documented (Shahi, 1985 and Mukhopadhyayand Banerjee, 1990). However, studies on the effect of herbicide mixtures and sequential applications on weed flora in transplanted rice are limited. Hence, an investigation was carried out to study the influence of different herbicide mixtures alone and in sequence with 2, 4-DEE on relative composition of weed flora in transplanted rice. The field experiment was conducted during the kharif seasons of 1991 and …

title: Achievement of children in relation to feeding, height and age.
abstract: Studied the achievement of 84 upper-and middle-income elementary school children in relation to infant-feeding practices, nutrition, SES, and height and age. Ss whose SES was above the median had significantly better scholastic performance than those below the median. All the respondent families had a poor concept of an adequate diet. This led to a faulty day's dietary intake because of the wrong food preferences made and hence could be one of the contributory causes of poor academic performance. No relationship between achievement and height and age was found. The need for nutrition education is emphasized.(PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Spatial variability of some properties of a typic ustochrept soil in the semiarid region of Northwestern India
abstract: Estimation of random and spatial variability of soil properties of a Typic Ustochrept in the semiarid region of northwestern India showed that pH, electrical conductivity, organic carbon, available P, and available K were normally distributed. Soil pH exhibited least variation (CV = 2%), followed by EC and organic carbon; available P showed the highest variation (CV = 59%). Semivariograms showed that only pH and EC conformed to second‐order stationarity; both had a range of 24 m. A continuous variation was observed in organic carbon and available P and K contents, showing thereby that krigging cannot be used for intrapolation of these properties.

abstract: Les plantes diploïdes compensatrices nouvelles sont très rares chez les espèces diploïdes. Cette étude a visé à décrire l'origine, l'identité et les comportements de la méiose et des croisements de deux diploïdes compensatrices d'orge (Hordeum vulgare L.), isolées chez le cultivar de printemps à deux rangs 'Shin Ebisu 16' (SE16). Une plante à 2n = 13 + 1 acro3L3s + 1 télo3S a été identifiée cytologiquement chez une population F2 issue d'un croisement 2n = 14 + 1 acro3L3s + 1 télo3L3s × yst 2 (à 2 rayures jaunes). Chez cette plante, le 1 acro3L3s et le 1 télo3S ont compensé un chromosome 3 normal. Dans la population autogame dérivée de cette plante, trois types chromosomiques ont habituellement ségrégé dans le ratio 1 (2n = 14) : 2 (2n = 13 + 1 acro3L3s + 1 télo3S) : 1 (2n = 12 + 2 acro3L3s + 2 télo3S). title: Integrated Weed Management in Direct Sown Upland Rice
abstract: Weeds compete severaly with rice and cause drastic reduction in grain yield. Weeds alone have been reported to reduce yield by 50-60% in direct sown upland rice (PiUai and Rao, 1974). The combined application of chemical, mechanicial weed control practices are cheaper and effective than hand weeding as reported by Ali et al.(1985).The present experiment was conducted on a sandy loam soil at Research Farm of Institute of Agricultural Sciences, Banaras HinduUniversity, Varanasi during kharif seasonof 1985 to study the effec~ of integrated methods of weed control in direct sown upland rice. Eleven treatments (Table-I) were tested in a randomized block design with three replications. The crop was fertilized with recommended dose of N, P, K,@ 60, 10, 30 kg/ha, respectively. Half dose of nitrogen and full dose of Pto, and Ka were applied at the time of sowing and remaining half dose of nitrogen was top …

title: Biomass, net primary production and nutrient cycling in Quercus leucotrichophora forest in the central Himalayas
abstract: This paper describes net primary production and nutrient cycling in a Q. leucotrihchophora forest. Allometric equations relating bio-mass and tree dimensions to circumference at breast height (cbh) were significant. The relationship between total aboveground bio-mass and biomass of different components and dan were also significant. The biomass of the vegetation was 390x109 kg ha'. Trees accounted for 99%, shrubs for 0.6% and herbs for 0.3% of the total dry matter. Net primary production was 15.8 t ha'. The share of trees, shrub and herb layers in total net production was 83.5, 12.7 and 4.2%, respectively. The nutrient concentrations were of the order: herbs> shrubs> trees. Soil, litter and vegetation accounted for 51.2-63.5%, 0.5-1.8% and 36.0-47.0% of total nutrients. About 5.3-23.9% retranslocation of nutrients occurred during senescence. The uptake of nutrients by vegetation has been estimated. Annual transfer of litter to the soil by tree layer was 74. 5 N, 4.36 P, 23.6 K kg ha lyr'. Turnover rate and turnover time for different nutrients ranged between 65-82% and 1.22· 1.54 years, respectively.

title: Effect of moisture variation on seed physiology
abstract: An experiment was conducted in 1990 to study the effect of moisture on thermal conductivity of seeds of wheat (Triticum aestivum L. emend. Fiori & Paol.). moth bean (Phaseolus aconitifolius Jacq.) and lentil (Lens culinaris Medikus). Moisture content and thermal conductivity were measured by oven-dry technique and by probe method respectively. The thermal conductivity of seeds of all the crops increased with increase in moisture content (in wheat from 0.098 to 0.239, in lentil from 0.093 to 0.358 and in moth bean from 0.113 to 0.206 W/m/(o)K).

title: Ontogeny of behavioral dynamics among free-ranging rhesus monkeys (Macaca mulatta) theory and observation
abstract: ISSUES IN BEHAVIORAL ONTOGENY Rhesus ontogeny, starts with cell fusion, through gestation and parturition leads to post natal life. The dynamic aspect of life acts alongside each other during pre-and post-natal life with cellular growth and differentiation. On attainment of maturity, mitosis and differentiation are much reduced, function continues though for the most part with reduced efficiency, leads towards and until death. This may be the most parimonious description of the life process.An analogous model with a behavioral framework to biological development has not been formulated so far, rather abundant stockpile of research makes the problem more complex due to involvement of many issues. Behavioral ontogeny of a rhesus monkey too onsets with cell fusion. Although, Carmichael (1946) expressed reservations on assuming behavioral capability of a zygote and interrogated the starting point of behavioral ontogeny. Limited response repertoire of single celled organisms has been amply demonstrated (Cominglvon Burg, 1972). Behavioral repertoire (a set of discrete responses an organism is capable of emmitting) increases parallel to cellular growth in a post zygotic organism and undergoes various fonns of changes throughout life. Nature-nurture controversy has also plagued the field of behavioral ontogeny. The basic genetic individuality can be assumed to be at the starting point of development (except pure lines and identical twins). An anthropolgist claims that so slim are the chances of duplication that each living being

title: Adsorption Thermodynamics of Carbofuran on Forest and Black Soils
abstract: Thermodynamics of adsorption of carbofuran (2, 3-dihydro-2, 2- dimethy 1-7-benzofuranyl methyl carbamate; a systemic non-ionic nematicide) was studied on two different types of Indian soils viz. a forest loam and black silt clay loam at 30° and 60°C. The adsorption isotherms conformed to the Freundlich adsorption model and yielded ‘S’ class isotherms. The amount of carbofuran adsorbed was higher in forest loam soil which also had a lower pH and higher organic matter content as compared to the black silt clay soil. The thermodynamic, parameters such as thermodynamic equilibrium constant Ko, standard free energy Δ T°, enthalpy Δ H° and entropy Δ S° changes for adsorption have been calculated.

title: A study of the formation of the neural network in the lungs of Perdicula asiatica, as revealed by the cholinesterase technique.
abstract: The investigation was undertaken to investigate the formation and association of neural network and their fibres with nerve cells and ganglia in the parenchyma. The staining of the neural network was done by the cholinesterase technique under the maintained pH 5.2, temperature 40 degrees C and incubation period 30 hrs. The neural network was formed by a good number of tortuous thick nerves and was related either with nerve cells or ganglia. At times, it was formed by a good number of thick nerves and a few thin nerves in the connective tissue space.

title: Stability of two superposed homogeneous fluids under uniform magnetic field
abstract: The instability of two superposed homogeneous fluids is discussed under gravitational force and uniform magnetic field. The perturbation propagation is taken simultaneously along and perpendicular to streaming motion in the horizontal plane z=0. The critical wave numberk * has been found and some special cases of interest are discussed.

title: EFFECT OF INTERCROPS ON PERFORMANCE AND PRODUCTION ECONOMICS OF TOMATO (LYCOPERSICON-ESCULENTUM)
abstract: An experiment was conducted during winter seasons of 1987-88 and 1988-89 at Ranchi to study the feasibility of intercropping winter-season 'Arka Abha' tomato (Lycopersiconesculentum Millernom. cons.) with 'Arkel' pea (Pisum sativum L. sensu lato), 'Arka Komal' french bean (Phaseolus vulgaris L.), 'Japanese White' radish (Raphanus sativus L.), local fenugreck (Trigonellafoenum-graecum L.) and 'Arka Niketan' onion (Allium cepa L.) in 2 or 3 crop combinations.  Planting 4 rows of onion 15 cm apart between 2 rows of tomato (30 cm x 100 cm) gave 36% higher tomato-equivalent yield without significantly affecting the number, average weight and marketable yield of tomato fruits.  Radish as an intercrop showed the maximum adverse effect on yield (54%) and yield equivalents (27%) of tomato.  The intercropping systems did not show any adverse effect on the stand of crop in winter.  Tomato + onion combination …

title: Development of Suitable Growing Conditions in Usar Land for Fish Production
abstract: Introduction In the country 7 million bectares area is identified as usar land and Uttar Pradesh alone has 1.3 million hectares (Abrol and Bhumbla, 1971). The usar land is characterised by high pH and presence of indurated clay and hard gravels (kankar pan) in the soil at various depths. The physical and chemical properties of soil of usar land are highly deteriorated and it has excess of soluble salts and/or high exchangeable sodium percentage with poor fertility. Therefore, it is considered as unsuitable for adopting agri-cultural as well as fish culture practices. The main problems for adopting fish culture practice in this land are construction of ponds, seepage in pond and adverse conditions of soil which make pond water unfavourable for the survival and growth of the fishes. The unfavourable water characters are like high pH, high turbidity and low dissolved oxygen. All these adverse characters of pond water render the usar ponds unhospitable for survival and growth of the stocked fishes satisfactorily. Sincere efforts have been made by many workers, namely, Abrol et al.(1973), Dhankar and Abrol (1980), Dhar and Mukherji (1936), Gaul and

title: EFFECT OF IRRIGATION REGIMES AND NITROGEN DOSES ON OAT (AVENA-SATIVA) VARIETIES
abstract: A field experiment was conducted during the winter seasons (rabi) of 1985-86 and 1986-87 at New Delhi to find out the effect of irrigation regimes and N doses on oat (Avena sativa L.). 'Pusa Oat 1' outyielded Kent' and 'Pusa Oat 5'. Irrigation at 0.8 irrigation water: cumulative pan evaporation (IW : CPF) ratio, being on a par with 1.0, gave 10.2% higher yield than at 0.6 ratio.  Grain yield increased with an increase in N dose up to 80 kg N; however, economic dose was worked out to be 64 kg.  The straw yield also followed the same trend as regards the response to irrigation and N.

title: Diagnostics and propagation of radiation from lightning discharges
abstract: The role of stepped leader channel ionization on return current flow has been studied. It is shown that for Te > Ti, the downward traversing electron beam in the stepped leader ionized channel gives rise to plasma oscillations with a finite decay rate. The electron beam propagating downward and ion beam propagating upward give rise to resulting return current. The return current in the lightning channel may become oscillatory as a result of plasma wave interaction. The electromagnetic radiation from an oscillatory return current source becomes variable. Such variations in recorded whistler intensity are often observed in whistler sonograms.

title: Characterizations and construction of E-optimal block designs
abstract: This paper studies the E-optimality of block designs within sub-classes of competing designs with varying replications and unequal block sizes. Several sufficient conditions have been obtained for a design to be E-optimal within the classes considered. Some methods of constructing E-optimal designs in these sub-classes, satisfying the sufficient conditions have been given.

The significant difference was observed with respect to all the seven value dimensions as measured by the test. The data was int erpretted in ihe context of present social and political situations prevailing in the region.

title: Mechanical control of Gurdaspur borer (Acigona steniella (Hmpsn.)) in Yamunanagar (Haryana).
abstract: see more details, between 1979 and 1989 is described. Removing and destroying infested sugarcane shoots at weekly intervals from July to September for several years was found to be an effective method of controlling the pest in both upland and lowland sugarcane growing areas.

title: Heat and momentum fluxes and their spectra over the western coast of India during Monex-1979
abstract: The heat and momentum transport over western coast of Indian subcontinent have been computed using Monex-79 data and its vertical distribution in troposphere is examined. These fluxes are decomposed into seasonal mean and the eddy component due to local circulations. The relative contributions of mean and eddy transport at each level in the vertical from, surface to 300mb are examined. The vertical means of eddy component of heat and momentum fluxes are subjected to spectral analysis. Remarkable variations in periodicities with latitude over west coast of India ill these fluxes are noticed. The eddy latent heat flux shows larger periodicity as compared with eddy sensible heat and eddy momentum flux

title: Performance-oriented scaling laws for mixed analog/digital MOS circuits
abstract: A novel approach, in which S/N performance is taken as the key figure, is presented for scaling of mixed analog/digital circuits. S/N performance is severely degraded by other popular scaling laws. The proposed laws, (i) hold the low-frequency S/N ratio a constant (ii) are, in general, compatible with the present popular trends in scaling, and can also (iii) improve the required d.c. or a.c. response of the scaled circuits. Improved MOS analog circuit performance is verified by SPICE simulations.

title: Role of press in creating environmental awareness
abstract: The promotion of public awareness of environment apart from other things sensitizes authorities to the quality of lifee in urban and rural areas. The citizens interest in and concern for environmental issues at all levels can not grow unless they are. informed and educated by both the authorities and by those who are knowledgeable in environmental and related matters. Such information and public education lead to the development of useful and current environmental attitudes and feelings of concern.(Nagcboudhari, 1983>.The success of management of environment is largely dependent on the public support of the environmental issaasV Public awareness can be built through information support ohly.'Newspaper is the source of building awareness and changing attitude. title: A report on relative acid phosphatase activity in liver of murrel species.
abstract: The purpose of this study is to examine acid phosphatase activity in the liver of four murrel species in the genus Channa viz C. marulius, C. gachua, C. punetatus and C. striatus . These species were collected from stagnant muddy waters of Indore. Fish liver was isolated in prechilled medium, cleared of unwanted tissue, weighed and sliced.

title: Philosophy of defence in plants
abstract: Plants are constantly exposed to millions of micro-organisms and many of these microbes possess the faculty to attack plants. However, in nature disease is more an exception than a rule. Most of the microbes surrounding the plant are saprophytic, incapable of attacking a healthy plant. Only a few are pathogenic, but each one of these can only attack specific plant species. Furthermore, all the individuals of a host species are not equally susceptible to a given pathogen isolate. How are most of the microbes in contact with the plant surface rendered harmless? How does a plant defend itself against non-pathogens (pathogens of other species) and pathogens? In humans and higher animals, there is a central defence system which protects the entire body against any microbial or viral attack. The role of a localized defence system is very limited. Plants, by virtue of their peculiar morphology, anatomy and physiology, have evolved their defence systems on entirely different lines from animals. Quite often we have tended to draw analogies between the two defence systems, for example phytoalexins were once considered to be a functional analogue of the immune system in animals and, recently, there has been a lot of enthusiasm about finding similarities between b proteins in plants with animal interferons (see Chapter 7). A critical analysis of defence mechanisms in plants and animals in the light of their requirements reveals that the very basic philosophy of defence in plants is altogether different from that in animals. Unlike animals, plants cannot move; they cannot side step or run away from an attacking pathogen. They are bound to stand, wait and …

title: Synthesis and spectral characterization of cobalt (III) complexes of N-(o-carboxyphenyl) iminodiacetic acid
abstract: The complexes [Co(cpida)(N–N)]·nH2O [H3cpida =N-(o-carboxyphenyl)iminodiacetic acid, N–N = ethylenediamine, 1,2-diaminopropane, or 1,3-diaminopropane] have been synthesized from trans-[Co(N–N)2Cl2]+ as well as by direct oxidation procedures. The dinitro complex Na2[Co(cpida)(NO2)2] has been synthesized from Na3[Co(NO2)4(CO3)]. They have been characterized by u.v.–visible, i.r., and 1H n.m.r. spectroscopy. The amine spectral pattern and the acetate splitting in the 1H n.m.r. offers valuable information about the geometry of the ligand around the metal ion.

title: Estimation of vapor pressures of organic nitrogen and sulfur compounds by a group-contribution method
abstract: The group-contribution method for vapor pressures of hydrocarbons and organic compounds containing nitrogen or sulfur, based on the kinetic theory of fluids, is revised and extended to include new groups containing nitrogen or sulfur. Good representation is obtained for vapor pressure data in the region 1.30-270 kPa. The method may be used to estimate vapor pressures and enthalpies of vaporization for those organic fluids containing nitrogen or sulfur, where no experimental data are available.

title: A test of the bay-region mechanism in carcinogenesis for monomethyl benz [a] anthracenes in a self-consistent-field molecular orbital theory
abstract: The relative carcinogenic activity of the isomeric monomethyl derivatives of benz[a]anthracene has been studied on the basis of their bay-region reactivity, and the subsequent ease of carbonium ion formation, as obtained from a suitable ‘self-consistent-field’ molecular orbital theory for the mobile π-electrons. The predicted order of carcinogenic activity of these molecules is compared with the available experimental data.

title: An approach to the design of optimum production blast pattern from single hole blast results
abstract: The basic function of blasting is to break the rock and to displace it into a muckpile. In any, fragmentation can be improved or deteriorated if burden, spacing and explosive distribution in the boreholes are changed. A common practice to achieve optimum blast design is the trial and error method. In this paper an approach is dealt with showing how optimum blast conditions were achieved by single hole blasting during two field investigation. The method used involve blasting of only one hole at a time at successively increasing burdens. Post-blast results of all holes indicated formation of a triangular bench crater. Angel of breakage, back break and the maximum fragment size were recorded after blasting at various burdens. Optimum production blasts were designed based on the results of single hole blasting.

title: Effect of Azotobacter Exudates on Certain Micro‐Fungi Associated with the Phylloplane of Soybean
abstract: The effect of different concentrations of Azotobacter chroococcum exudates on microfungi isolated from Soybean phylloplane was studied in vitro and in vivo. It has been found that the growth of some fungi was stimulated or suppressed whereas others showed fluctuations or remained unaffected depending upon the age of the plant, growth stage of the leaf, concentration of the exudates, method used to harvest fungi, and environmental conditions. Nutrient competition or production of biologically active substances like GA may be responsible for retarding the growth of fungi.

title: 50 Diurnal Variation in Plasma Calcium Concentration
abstract: Circadian variations of different blood and urinary constituents have been reported in man and laboratory animals [5-7, 9-10]. The complete standardization of such rhythms of subjects during a normal 24-h routine of sleeping, eating, working, activity, and so on is of great importance. Such references provide standards for different components of the circadian system, which are needed to compare such rhythms in health and disease. The existing knowledge on the circadian rhythm of plasma calcium does not show a consistent pattern. Therefore, the present study was planned to study circadian changes, if any, in the total plasma calcium concentration of healthy young Indians.

title: Choice of parents in grape hybridization
abstract: Extensive hybridization work carried out for two years employing commercial grape cultivars showed maximum percent seed-set on pollinating Bangalore Blue with Black Champa. On the basis of seed germination, Cheeema Sahebi, Anab-e-Shahi and Bangalore Blue were found to be good female parents. Maximum seed germination was obtained in the cross between Cheema Sahebi and Anab-e-Shahi. Seed germination in Black Champa was very poor. Hybrid evaluation for berry and bunch shape and appearance indicated that the cross combinations—Black Champa×Anab-e-Shahi, Black Champa × Thompson Seedless, Anab-e-Shahi × Black Champa, Anab-e-Shahi × Queen of the Vineyards and Angur Knlan, × Convent Large Black were very prospective.

title: Initial dyadic social behavior in free-ranging rhesus monkeys (Macaca mulatta)
abstract: Initial dyadic social interactions of 13 rhesus monkeys were observed in a free-ranging group of 26 members. Each subject was observed for 900 intervals of 20 sec each by focal animal method. The obtained matrix of approach interactions was separately analyzed in relation to sex and dominance level of interacting animals. Dominance ranks were determined by approach-withdrawal scores and its validity was assessed with other submissive scores. Chi-square analysis revealed a significant preference for opposite sexed animals. High ranked animals initiated more social interactions than was expected; however, other animals approached less towards them. It is concluded that in free-ranging group situations, members do not interact at random, rather their interactions are patterned by individual characteristics, such as age, sex and relative dominance level in the group hierarchy.

title: Extension of Potential-pH Diagrams to Concentrated Aqueous Solutions
abstract: A thermodynamic framework has been developed to evaluate the equilibrium potentials of halfcell reactions for various metals in concentrated alkaline solutions for electrolyte concentrations from 1 to 8 mol kg and over the temperature range-10 to 120 C. An analysis of the thermodynamic properties of concentrated LiOH, NaOH, and KOH solutions was carried out to provide data for the activity of water, the activity coefficient of the hydroxide ion, and the pH of the electrolyte. Potential-pH relations have then been derived for various equilibrium phenomena for the metals Al, Fe, Ni, and Zn in these electrolyte systems.

title: Meiotic behaviour in a hypertriploid plant of pearl millet (Pennisetum americanum (L.) K. Schum)
abstract: A hypertriploid (2n= 22) was detected in the progeny of a partially desynaptic trisomic (2n= 15) plant of pearl millet. The hypertriploid differed in morphology from its maternal trisomic-sibs, but showed comparable morphology with those of triploids. The microsporocytes showed a mean chromosome associations of 2.34 (I)+ 2.96 (II)+ 4.43 (III)+ 0.1 (IV) at metaphase I with a mean chiasmata number of 13, 40 per cell. The twenty types of observed chromosome configurations could be explained by assuming that plant was trisomic for six chromosomes and tetrasomic for one chromosome. Four chromosome associations such as 5 (II)+ 4 (III), 1+ 6 (II)+ 3 (III), 2 (I)+ 7 (II)+ 2 (III) and 8 (II)+ 2 (III) suggested the presence of displaced duplications or small interchange within the genome of pearl millet. The tetrasomic chromosome formed mostly a quadrivalent which often broke down to form 2 (II) or 1 (I)+ 1 (III) and rarely 2 (I)+ 1 (II) or 4 univalents. Most of the univalents arose from the trisomic chromosomes. Abnormal distribution of chromosomes at AI resulted in the formation of diads and tetrads with unequal chromosome numbers. The plant was highly sterile but set some seeds upon open pollination.

title: Combining ability in relation to soybean breeding Glycine max (L.) Merrill
abstract: Combining ability was studied in a 6 x 6 diallel set of soybean [Glycine max (L.) Merr.] for seed yield and its components. Analysis of variance for treatment showed a wide range of variability. Both general and specific combining ability variances were significant. The higher magnitude of gca variance indicated the importance of additive and additive x additive components of genetic variance in the inheritance of these characters. Monetta and EC 7034 were best general combiners for a majority of traits. Five F1 hybrids, viz. Bragg x Wills, EC 7034 x Hernon 49 Monetta x Hernon 49, EC 7034 x Monetta and Punjab-1 x EC 7034 were identified as promising and their use in hybrid breeding programs in soybean would be most advantageous.[AS/SS]

title: Weed control in upland rice as affected by weed control treatments
abstract: Field experiments were carried out to study the effect of herbicides on the growth of associated weeds and yield of direct seeded upland rice (Oryza sativa L.). The major weed population in the experimental field consisted of broadleaf annuals (Phyllathus niruri L., Ammonia baccifera L.), grass annuals (Echinochloa colona (L.) Link, and Echinochloa crus-galli L. Beauv.). Propanil (3', 4-dichloropropionanilide) was found most effective against grasses and sedges, whereas butachlor (2-chloro-2'), 6'-diethyl-N-(butoxymethyl acetanilide),(L and G) was more effective against broadleaf weeds. In the phenoxy group, MCPA (2-methyl-4-chlorophenoxyacetic acid) was found most effective against sedges. Propanil and butachlor (L and G) reduced weed competition and produced higher grain yield. 2, 4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acid (2, 4-D) and MCPA were most ineffective and caused more weed dry matter accumulation throughout the crop growth period

title: Nonlinear theory of two stream instability in the presence of magnetic field
abstract: The method of perturbation has been applied to study the nonlinear development of two stream instability of a magnetized hot plasma in the presence of two finite temperature electron beams with the help of macroscopic equations. A nonlinear Schrodinger equation governing the finite amplitude wave has been derived. It has been found that the nature of axisymmetric potential is completely changed due to the presence of the magnetic field. The values of omega and k for the marginal instability increase with the increasing magnetic field. The range of the wave numbers for the instability of higher harmonics decrease due to the magnetic field. All the disturbances grow up until overtaking occurs, the growth rate being enhanced by nonlinear effects. The occurrence of modulational instability has also been predicted.

title: Gel electrophoretic studies in relation to pea (Pisum sativum L.) varietal identification
abstract: Ten varieties of pea of varying height groups, protein contents and resistance to powdery mildew, along with four Fis were analysed for soluble seed protein banding patterns by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. The varieties had considerable variation in their profiles. Some variety-specific bands were found. Bands 19 and 20, present in almost all the susceptible varieties and their Fıs, were suggested as codominant alleles of the single locus. Results indicated recessive gene control for resistance to powdery mildew. In general, more similarity was observed between the varieties of same height group and more genetic diversity between varieties of two different height groups. Presence of more number of bands in F1s, as compared to their respective parents, provides a basis for the greater biochemical diversity of the hybrids over pure lines. Two crosses showed partial dominance whereas two showed over dominance for the number of protein bands.

title: Disposition of norepinephrine in the isolated caecorectum preparation of chick
abstract: . Disposition of (-) notepinephrine (NE) in the isolated caecorectal preparation of chick was studiedby recording cumulative dose response curves with (-) NE alone and in the presence of specific inhibitor of the mechanisms of amine inactivation and by using oil immersion technique. Relaxant effect of NE (10-5M) on caecorectum of chick contracted with carbachol was potentiated by about 43% with cocaine (3x 10-5M), 23% with iproniazid (10-4M) and 17% with tropolone (10-4M). The results of oil immersion technique indicated that" t50" was increased almost similarly after inhibition of uptake process, monoamine oxidase (MAO) or catechol-O methyl transferase (COMT). The results suggest that neuronal uptake was as important as the role payed by both COMT and MAO taken together. This is in contrast to that reported in mammalian tissues where the uptake process contributes mainly in the disposition of NE.

title: M-FLATNESS AND M           I           -FLATNESS
abstract: In this paper it is shown that if M is a flat R-module over a commutative integral domain then any module U is flat relative to , Mi = M if and only if U is flat relative to all M-duals. Although M-projectivity does not always imply M-flatness, as is shown by a counter example, a condition under which implication holds has been provided. A necessary and sufficient condition for all right R-module to be M-flat has also been obtained.

title: Effect of Different Pollinators on Seed-Set in Certain Male-Sterile Grape Cultivars
abstract: In male-sterile grape varieties—Angur Kalan, Coarna Rosie, Hur and Katta Kurgan, effect of different pollen parents was studied with respect to per cent berry-set, number of sinker seeds and seed-set frequency. The male parents behaved differently in getting seeded berry in different male -sterile varieties. Highest mean set was found in Katta Kurgan with Thompson Seedless and the lowest in Angur Kalan with Cheema Sahebi. The best combinations with seeded berry-set over 30 per cent were Angur Kalan × Balgalore Purple, Angur Kalan × Cardinal, Hur × Anab-e-Shahi and Katta Kurgan × Thompson Seedless.

title: Some New Cobalt (III) Complexes of Triazene I-Oxides
abstract: Materials and MethodsThe different ligands used were synthesized by the general methodt+ involving diazotization of the corresponding aniline and coupling it with the required hydroxylamine. Normal oxidation of cobalt-(II) in the presence of required amount of ligand always resulted in coba1t (II) chelates already reported while the hexamine cobaltic chloride method gave an impure product which was difficult to purify, The addition of cobalt (III) tricarbonate solution to an ethanolic solution of appropriate ligand with vigorous stirring produced dark-violet tris chelates which on recrystallization from a mixture of hexane and dichloromethane gave pure products.Characterization of the complexes was done on the basis of C, Hand N analyses. Magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out on solids using Gouy method. Electronic spectra were recorded on a Cary 14 spectrophotometer in benzene using quartz …

title: Economies of Cropping Pattern in the District of Jaunpur, UP
abstract: Objectives The main objectives of the study are: 1. To study the cropping pattern of the farms of different sizes. 2. To work out the economies of different crop rotations on different size groups of farms. 3. To study the influence of the cropping pattern on net income of farms of different sizes, Methodology The study is based on an intensive inquiry of 100 cultivators, selected randomly under four size groups viz. Ol, 1-2, 2-2 and above hectares from ten villages of Sikrara Block, district Jaunpur. Three stage stratified random sampling technique was used to select the block, villages and the cultivators. The number of cultivators under each size group was kept in probable proporation to their number falling under each size group. The inquiry was made during the year 1973-74.

title: Effect of chlorinated hydrocarbons (insecticides) on fermentation processes
abstract: Chlorinated hydrocarbons inhibit the fermentation processes in Aspergillus niger and Saccharomyces cerevisiae. Production of citric acid by A. niger was reduced by 40 to 60% as compared to the control in the presence of heptachlor, endrin, dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane and lindane (40 ..mu..g/ml). Similar inhibition pattern was also observed on the formation of ethyl alcohol by S. cerevisiae. Initial steps of fermentation do not seem to be affected by chlorinated hydrocarbons as sugar utilization is not inhibited by these compounds.

title: Fertilizer use in rainfed crops-grain yield and nitrogen uptake
abstract: Effects of the application of 20-80 kg N/ha by 3 methods on N uptake in 3 kharif [summer monsoon] crops maize, sorghum and bajra [Pennisetum americanum] and 4 rabi [winter] crops wheat, barley, sarson [Brassica napus var. glauca] and oilseed flax on sandy loam soil under rain-fed conditions at Delhi were determined. The total N uptake in kharif crops increased with increasing N levels. N uptake in barley and sarson was highest with 80 and 60 kg N/ha, respectively; it was highest in oilseed flax with 20 kg N/ha. N uptake was higher with N placed 10 cm deep in the soil or when 50% N was placed in soil and the remainder applied as a foliar spray than when applied broadcast. The N utilization efficiency was highest in bajra, followed by maize, oilseed flax, sorghum, sarson, barley and wheat. The utilization of soil N was highest in sarson and bajra

title: Determination of stability constants of some bivalent metal complexes with thiovioluric and diphenylthiovioluric acids
abstract: Stability constants of complexes of some bivalent metal ions, viz, Cu(II), Ni(II), Zn(II), Pb(II) and Mg(II) with thiovioluric and diphenylthiovioluric acid have been determined potentiometrically in 50 and 75% dioxan media, respectively. The order of stability constants for the complexes investigated has been found to be: Mn < Ni < Cu > Zn. The stability of lead complexes has been found to be intermediate between Mn(II) and Ni(II) while magnesium forms the least stable complexes.

title: Dynamics of Integrated Area Development in India
abstract: In the process of development of a region, the transfer of resources takes place from farm to non-farm business and vice versa. In the absence of proper planning and co-ordination of these two economic activities, the development of the region may not take place to the desired extent and in feasible direction even if there is abundant supply of all production requisites needed to accelerate the rate of growth. Realising the importance of such a co-ordination, the scheme of growth centres has been launched in 20 selected areas of the country to attain a balanced growth of the locale. For clarity and common understanding, some of the ambiguities and doubts relating to these programmes need to be removed and issues thoroughly discussed. Some of the issues may pertain to the concept and activities of the growth centre, the optimum size of a hinterland, a convenient locale, criteria for isolation of backward and …
